Species of rodent
| Baluchistan pygmy jerboa

| **_Salpingotulus michaelis_**  
(FitzGibbon, 1966)
 |
The **Baluchistan pygmy jerboa** (_**Salpingotulus michaelis**_) or **dwarf three-toed jerboa**, is a species of  in the family . It is the only species in the genus _**Salpingotulus**_. Adults average only 4.3 cm (1.7 in) in head and body length, with the tail averaging 8 cm (3.1 in). Adult females weigh 3.2 g (0.11 oz).] It is currently considered to be  to .] In the 1999 , it was listed as tied for the smallest rodent in the world with the .]
Distribution
------------
\\]
The species has been recorded from Pakistan and may occur in Afghanistan. It frequents sand dunes, gravel flats and plains in hot deserts.]
Ecology
-------
\\]
These nocturnal jerboas move through its dry desert habitat in long hops, balancing with the tail. They live in burrows generally excavated under small bushes. They feed on wind blown seeds, succulent leaves of desert-adapted vegetation, and various dead animals such as other rodents and lizards; food is raised to the mouth using the hands. As plants dry up, they are often left to dig up roots of desert plants and feast on them. They are omnivores. They undergo a  of physiological , when their bodily functions, including respiration and blood circulation, slow...[Content truncated]

This directly informs the question about identifying features that distinguish it from other small rodents in the video and helps to validate or refute the claim about the rodent's identity.

metatags.twitter:creator: Ehmee
metatags.twitter:title: thebrainscoop
metatags.og:title: The Brain Scoop
metatags.twitter:description: Dipodidae Nobody quite got Friday’s Freak of the Week – amischiefofmice and rolypolypellmell came in the ballpark with their guesses of ‘kangaroo rat’, which is a relatively close assumption,...

website_content.content:
_**Dipodidae**_
Nobody quite got  – 
]
  and
]  came in the ballpark with their guesses of ‘kangaroo rat’, which is a relatively close assumption, however kangaroo rats are members of the family Heteromyidae.  Members of that family are more closely related to members of the pocket gopher family, Geomyidae. Most of the specimens photographed today are members of the family Dipodidae, which includes .
I’ve actually posted about that incredibly special individual before when I came across it  – it is the Baluchistan pygmy jerboa, aka the dwarf three-toed jerboa – _Salpingotulus michaelis –_ and is the only species in the genus _Salpingotulus_.  In addition to the remarkable fact that this specimen is a rare sight in its native Pakistan habitat, back in 1967 it was confirmed that our museum was one of only five museums in the entire world to have one of these guys in their collection!
The other specimens photographed include the two largest jerboas identified as ’_Allactaga jaculus_’, which apparently is an outdated nomenclature combining two genera instead of a genus and a species name, so I can’t be positive what they actually are.  The third largest is Ord’s kangaroo rat (_Dipodomys ordii)_ of the family Heteromyidae, included to show the similarities between members of the same family.  To contrast, the second-to-smallest is the western jumping mouse (_Zapus princeps)_ which is in the family Dipodidae, but looks less similar than the Ord’s kangaroo rat.  WHEW – did you get all of that?!
Secondly, a gigantic THANK YOU to everyone who left comments and sent messages for suggestions on improving this blog!  I’m so pleased to see so many of you invested and interested in this project, and really value your input, so a tremendous thanks again.
Did I mention that you can now  texts/video/photos/ for identification?! I don’t know why I didn’t enable this feature sooner!  Stay tuned for another post later today where I will talk about some identification techniques, and mention a few good books for ID reference.  It’s going to be AWESOME

website_quality_evaluation.justification: The Brain Scoop is a blog and education platform focusing on natural history and science, operated by Emily Graslie. Its reliability varies due to being hosted on Tumblr, which is less regulated than academic publications.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This source reinforces the identity of the Baluchistan pygmy jerboa and provides context about its rarity and distribution. Although it doesn’t enumerate identifying features as directly as evidence0, it supports the claims made in evidence0 by establishing the uniqueness of the Baluchistan pygmy jerboa in comparison to other rodents.

4.  Rodents
Rodents
=======
(tel:150808)
(tel:150808 "Contact us")
Rodents make up the most numerous group of mammals, with 2277 species, accounting for 41% of the known mammals. They are a very diverse group in both size and habitat, ranging from the South American capybara weighing up to 66kg, to the Baluchistan pygmy jerboa, the female adults of which weigh less than 4gm.
### 
The house mouse is one of the most popular species of mice. Find out how to identify them, their habitats and their diet.

Types of Rodents
----------------
Rodents are found on every continent except Antarctica. They live in a wide range of different habitats from snow-covered tundra to hot deserts. Some species of rodent are also the common invaders of the human environment:

website_content.content:
[Content truncated]... authors to be in a separate genus, but its position on the phylogenetic tree constructed with use of morphological characteristics place it in the genus
                                 Salpingotus
                                , being sister group of Anguistodontus. Monotypic.
                            


                                 Distribution. SW Pakistan (Balochistan).
                                
View Figure



 Descriptive notes. Head-body 41-45 mm, tail 72-94 mm, ear 6-11 mm, hindfoot 18— 19 mm; weight 4 g. The Balochistan PygmyJerboa is very small. Condylo-basal lengths of skulls are 12:8-14-3 mm, mastoid breadths are 13-3-14-7 mm, and maxillary tooth row lengths are 2-6-2-8 mm. Head and dorsum are pale yellow-ocher or sandy buff; sides and ventral pelage are pure white. Tail is fatty, with relatively long black terminal tuft; fat deposits in tail are greatest in anterior one-third and rapidly become thinner toward tip. Hindfeet have three toes, covered below with brushes of white hairs; toes do not have conic calluses at bases. Ears are short and tubiform. Auditory bullae are greatly inflated and strongly project from under braincase laterally and caudally. Mastoid cavity is large and completely subdivided into three sections by septum. In volume, mastoid cavity is about twice as large as tympanic cavity. Front surfaces of incisors are yellow. P' is present and slightly smaller in diameter than M®. Molars are low-crowned, with tuberculous surfaces; crown heights of unworn molars are ¢.70% of their lengths. Glans penis is small, thin, elongated, cone-shaped, and not subdivided into lobes, with surface covered by very small single-vertex, backward-directed aciculae not differentiated in size. Os penis (baculum) is rudimentary and rachis-like; its length about equal to one-tenth of the length of glans penis.

 Habitat. Rolling sand dunes, sandy plains,orflat gravel plains with wind-moving sand layer in hot deserts at elevations of 1000-1600 m.

 Food and Feeding. The Balochistan Pygmy Jerboa mainly eats grass seeds and some other plant material.

 Breeding. Pregnant Balochistan Pygmy Jerboas were recorded in June-August...[Content truncated]

metatags.og:description: A jerboa’s tail is usually longer than its head and body combined. The jerboa is a small, hopping rodent that lives in the deserts of Northern Africa and Asia. Jerboas are very cute and have exceptionally long ears, tails, and hind feet that cause them to look like a caricature instead of a real animal. […]

This terrifyingly tentacled moth reminds us that nature is freakier than any nightmare
======================================================================================
Hard nope.
By 
Posted on Oct 25, 2017 9:15 PM EDT
7 minute read
!
Screenshot via Facebook
As I attempted to enjoy some homemade tomato soup on Sunday evening, _Popular Science_ Editor in Chief Joe Brown derailed my chill by sending me a video on Facebook. This video:
My friends, I am generally fascinated by the range of strangeness that mother nature puts on display. But I have to admit that I kind of hoped this clip would turn out to be some kind of hoax. It was just _too freaky_. The way that caterpillar-y butt looks too bulbous and heavy for the delicate moth body it sits atop. The sheer length of the four (count them, four) tentacles affixed at the end. The way those tentacles wiggled and writhed. The fact that they were _hairy_. It was simply too much.
Alas, a quick Google search identified this very real animal as , a moth found in Southeast Asia and Australia. Those furiously freaky tendrils are actually scent organs. The so-called coremata (also known as , which, ew) excrete pheromones, those scented hormones that many animals use to trigger certain behaviors in their fellow critters. The male, guided by the smell of a female’s own hormones, will unleash his hair-pencils (they’re usually stuffed inside the abdomen, which is somehow worse?) and flood the air with his own smelly signals. So, so romantic.
For those of us who aren’t from Australia, also known as the island-of-horrible-things-that-evolved-to-scare-and-kill-you, _Creatonotos gangis_ seems so strange as to be impossible. But just as these moths are unfortunately real, many other seemingly absurd creatures prove that evolution can go to some dark, dark places. Here are a few other examples:
Goblin sharks, ghost sharks, etc.
...[Content truncated]

website_content.content:
[Content truncated]...ed pygmy jerboa (Cardiocranius paradoxus) and the thick-tailed pygmy jerboa (Salpingotus crassicauda) -- are currently considered as threatened.  Other species -- for example, the long-eared jerboa (Euchoreutes naso), of the Gobi Desert, and the well known lesser Egyptian jerboa (Jaculus jaculus), of northern Africa and the Arabian Peninsula -- appear on the International Union for the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources Red List of Threatened Species, although they are ranked among those of "Least Concern." 
Some species, for instance, the long-eared jerboa, have been recommended for more research by international environmental organizations.  The jerboa's range, population trends, threats and management requirements need to be better understood if the animal is to be assured of long-term survival.
Interesting Facts

With further research, the jerboa's early development may yield new understanding of postnatal "anatomy, histology, physiology, and motor behavior," said Eilam and Shefer. 


Relative to the length of its front legs, the jerboa's back legs are longer than those of the kangaroo, according to the Encyclopedia Britannica, 9th Edition.


While unrelated, the jerboa, the Australian hopping mouse and the North American kangaroo rat have all developed similar adaptations to sandy, arid environments, providing an example of convergent evolution.


Extremely shy and elusive, the jerboa evades nearly any attempt at capture.  However, said the Encyclopedia Britannica, 9th Edition,"The Arabs...succeed, it is said, in this by closing up all the exits from the burrows with a single exception, by which therefore they are forced to come, and over which a net is placed for their capture." 


It is purportedly the jerboa -- referred to as a mouse -- that finds mention in the Bible, in the book of Leviticus, when the children of Israel are cautioned about they must not eat:  "These also shall be unclean to you among the creeping things that creep upon the earth:  the weasel, and the mouse, and the tortoise..."

metatags.twitter:title: Banded Linsang | Unsung Animals Wiki | Fandom
metatags.og:title: Banded Linsang
metatags.og:description: The banded linsang (Prionodon linsang) is a species of arboreal carnivoran, most closely related to cats that occurs in southeast Asia. Banded linsangs are long slender bodied animals, that have extremely cat-like facial features and behavioural characteristics and are a stark example of convergency between felines and their relatives. The banded linsang is superficially very cat-like, having a similar face and build. Comparatively, the banded linsang is much more slender and elongated, possessi
